text: and for the latest from Kiev I spoke to
the BBC's David Stern just a short time
ago I started by asking him about the
situation there tonight well this
situation the deadly situation continues
just about 50 meters down the road here
is Independence Square can hear the stun
grenades exploding the fighting
continues on one end of the square it's
not clear what the police are going to
ultimately do but they are moving into
the square slowly of course we have seen
fatalities today and running bells
between the anti-government protesters
police the worst violence so far if only
that it broke out in a number of places
around the Parliament before not before
now it has been concentrated in one area
now we see the violence spreading in
Kiev and the question is whether the
violence will spread even further maybe
in Kiev and possibly into the
countryside outside of the capital and
to the regions that are loyal to
President Viktor Yanukovych could this
be a critical moment in Ukraine's
political standoff well we've seen a
number of critical moment but yes it
does seem that it's reaching a head or
it's reaching another climax we don't
know what's going to happen tomorrow we
there are talks that the that the
government could introduce a crackdown
they say they will use all legal means
to restore stability now of course we
also have talks going on between the
opposition and president and the
government and and potentially protect
President Viktor Yanukovych but so far
these talks the talks in the past have
led nowhere the two sides are are
nowhere closer to reaching a compromise
the standoff continues and it seems that
the divisions at least tonight are
growing even deeper
